Award.AwardTitle: Towards a Safer and Greener Indoor Environment: Chemical Liberation from Polyethylene Plumbing Pipes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: 1228615 (Whelton). Over the past several decades, polymer potable water pipe use has exponentially increased. This trend is expected to continue because of cost and life-cycle advantages over metal pipes. Green building initiatives and the US Green Building Council (USGBC) are driving increased installation of high-density polyethylene (HDPE) and crosslinked polyethylene (PEX) potable water pipe into buildings to reduce PVC material use. Despite continued HDPE and PEX pipe installation, little is known about how US polyethylene based pipes affect drinking water quality, and data from Europe cannot be directly translated because of differences between pipe formulations and manufacturing practices. At present, little data are available on the conditions that result in worst-case contaminant release from US polyethylene potable water pipe. Moreover, little is known about which chemical and polymer properties best predict contaminant release potential, practically nothing about long-term drinking water quality impacts, and no US data are available from actual plumbing systems. This study will identify which contaminants, polymer properties, and environmental conditions influence contaminant release from new, laboratory aged, and actual pipes installed in building plumbing systems. The project will obtain the information necessary for building designers, owners, regulators, public health officials, and product manufacturers to understand the leaching aspects of HDPE and PEX piping. Results will outline key material factors so manufacturers can develop lower-leaching products, thereby improving building indoor environmental quality. A lab/field education module will be delivered to the USGBC Alabama and National Offices, AWWA, and US EPA. This module will also be provided to National and International Green Building Standard Organizations (IAMPO, ASPE).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plastic pipes can cause malodorous drinking water. Though, most publicly available plastic pipe water test results are for European pipes, not pipes available in America. European testing has revealed numerous potentially hazardous chemicals leaching out of plastic pipes into drinking water. In some cases, odor was caused for at least one year. When this project began, little was known about chemicals leaching into drinking water and how drinking water interacts with plastic pipes.

To conduct this study, Universities, corporations, and government agencies worked together. Drinking water was sampled from residential buildings that had crosslinked polyethylene (PEX) plumbing systems in Alabama, California, Colorado, Florida, Indiana, Maryland, Oklahoma, Virginia, and Washington. PEX is a commonly used plastic plumbing pipe. Testing revealed that typical drinking water tests (Environmental Protection Agency [EPA] Methods) do not often identify the compounds responsible for drinking water odor caused by PEX systems. One PEX system in Oklahoma caused the drinking water to have a gasoline-like odor. Another new PEX system elsewhere was removed and replaced at the homeowner’s request after complaining about bad drinking water odor. Results showed that whoever investigates drinking water quality in buildings should not exclusively rely on standard EPA methods, if they are interested in finding the cause of odor. Chemical composition of the drinking water entering the pipes, pipe age, plumbing system configuration, and frequency of flushing all contributed to each drinking water’s specific chemical make-up. Little generalizations can be drawn from one system to the next, necessitating laboratory studies.

For laboratory studies, potable water plastic pipes, marked with National Sanitation Foundation International Standard 61 certification, were purchased from common building supply stores. Chemical leaching was evaluated for PEX, high density polyethylene (HDPE), polypropylene (PP), and polyvinylchloride (PVC) pipes. Multiple PEX brands were tested though more than 70 brands reportedly exist. Laboratory tests showed that chemical leaching varied significantly across available pipe brands, within the same brand – and even within the same coil of PEX pipe. So, although the brand of pipe may be similar between buildings plumbed at the same time, chemical leaching could differ between those buildings. Also, because chemical leaching varied down the length of a single PEX pipe coil, leaching could differ in different parts of the building. Given that chemical make-up is variable and manufacturing materials are proprietary, we published on the suggested use of high-resolution mass spectrometry at plastic pipe manufacturing plants. This method can help identify the source of drinking water contamination from their pipes and examine when each batch of pipe is safe for use. This project also established that different brands of plastic pipes can enable microorganisms to grow. At present, no standards exist that limit chemical leaching, drinking water odor, or microbial growth from plastic pipes.

Generalities that could be made were that the greatest level of chemical leaching was detected for new pipes and levels decreased during each pipe’s 30 day test. Continued reductions in leaching past the 30 days are unknown. Higher water temperature sometimes caused greater chemical leaching than cold water. To limit the amount of chemicals people that inhabit buildings are potentially exposed to, it is recommended that new plastic plumbing be flushed out to facilitate leaching.

For the final phase of this project, PEX plumbing in a single-family residential home was intensely analyzed. Use of each faucet was monitored every second of every day. Water tests showed that less frequently used faucets contained water with greater microorganism levels and sometimes larger amounts of heavy metals. Drinking water odor differed throughout the house. Heavy metals like iron and lead (likely leached from metal fittings and from the water utility distribution system) accumulated on PEX pipe surfaces. Follow-up testing showed that heavy metals more rapidly accumulated on aged plastic compared to new plastic. A new compound to remove the heavy metals from the plastic pipe was tested. This “treatment” procedure will be optimized in future testing.

The public has shown great interest in this work. The project team responded to emails, telephone calls, and in person visits by members of the public, contractors, and trade industry representatives (i.e., pipes, water, etc.). The team also organized and participated in training workshops for water utilities, regulators, building designers, and contractors. Interviews with media outlets were also conducted and blog posts were posted at www.WheltonGroup.org. Presentations at technical water, health, and building construction conferences and meetings and university seminars were conducted. Results have been incorporated into a university undergraduate course, and helped make clear to much work is needed to better use technology in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. Results were published in top tier journals for water science, engineering, and building research. Additional results from this project, currently undergoing review and interpretation, are expected to be released in the future.
